) IRS personnel must follow the restrictions of IRC

if an organization claims to be a church. An organization may directly claim to be a church, or the IRS may infer it from facts and other characteristics that show the organi- zation holds itself out to be a church. IRS has developed fourteen criteria which it applies on an ad hoc basis to individual organizations. While some these are relatively minor, others are of central importance. Characteristics an organization holds itself out to be a church might include, for example: • The existence of an established congregation served by an organized ministry, • The provision of regular religious services and religious education for the young, and • The dissemination of a doctrinal code (

) If it is unclear whether the organization claims to be a church, the examiner should ask the organization during the ﬁrst contact if it claims to be a church. there is any doubt, the examiner will consult with Area Counsel to determine whether there are sufficient characteristics of a church to ask the organization whether it claims to be a church.
